item.title: Test Post
item.description: Testing, testing, 1, 2, 3… Here’s some R code and a figure: par(mfrow=c(2,1), mar=c(4,4,1,1)) plot(lynx, main = "Canadian Lynx Trappings", lwd=2) acf(lynx)

item.title: About
item.description: I’m an aquatic ecologist interested broadly interested in water quality, enviromental change, and data science. My research focuses on ecosystem resilience and regime shifts, algal blooms, and metabolism. I’m currently a Ph.D. candidate in the Pace Lab at the University of Virginia’s Department of Environmental Sciences. I completed my B.S. in 2014 at the University of Wisconsin in Biology and Mathematics.

item.title: Contact
item.description: Email: cbuelo10@gmail.com Mail: 291 McCormick Road P.O. Box 400123 Charlottesville, VA 22904

item.title: Research
item.description: Ecosystem Resilience & Regime Shifts Ecosystems are subject to constant pressure and disturbances from natural sources and human impacts. Resilience is the ability of an ecosystem to recover to its original state following a disturbance. Gradual or sudden decreases in ecosystem resilience can result in regime shifts - abrupt changes in the state of an ecosystem, due to transistions in the feedbacks that control system dynamics. These changes often seem to arise without warning, but theory suggests that regime shifts in a wide range of systems are preceeded by predictable changes in system statistical properties.
